The paper presents a method for developing powerful transfer learning models using sliced Wasserstein distance (SWD) loss. We analyze how this method can be applied to Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 satellite imagery and develop several extensions to make it effective in practice. In an application to few-shot Local Climate Zone (LCZ) prediction, we show that these networks outperform multiple common baselines on datasets with a large number of classes. Furthermore, we provide evidence that instance normalization can significantly stabilize the training process and that explicitly shaping the embedding space using supervised contrastive learning can lead to improved performance.

The United Nations has estimated that a large proportion of Sustainable Development Goal indicators can be measured through the use of geospatial data (Arnold et al., 2019). One example is land use and land cover mapping, which measures the health of populations, urban areas, and ecosystems over time. Urban areas are responsible for approximately 70% of the world's energy-related CO2 emissions, making it crucial to track the development of cities in climate change mitigation and adaptation (Lucon and Vorsatz, 2014). The interest in this topic has led to the collection of different forms of satellite data to map geospatial regions of the earth. Hyperspectral electro-optical (EO) images are one common form, with an abundance of large labeled datasets available. However, EO images have limitations, such as being blocked by clouds, limited by the day-and-night cycle, and subject to distortion under various weather conditions.

In situations requiring imaging over extended time periods, researchers have turned to Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data. SAR data is collected by a satellite sending out radar energy and recording the amount reflected back from the earth, making it less susceptible to the downsides of EO imaging. Unlike EO datasets, which can be easily interpreted and labeled through crowdsourcing, SAR data requires trained expertise for interpretation, resulting in limited and costly labeled datasets. One approach to extract information from geospatial data with few available labels is transfer machine learning. The idea is to pre-train a neural network on a source domain with plentiful data (i.e., EO) and then fine-tune on a target domain with limited data (SAR).

This paper focuses on a recent method by Rostami et al. (2019a, b), which uses sliced Wasserstein distance to align the distributions of the two modalities in a shared embedding space and promote knowledge transfer between the classification of EO and SAR images. This method allows for the use of few labeled SAR data and any available unlabeled data. However, the original work is limited in that it only analyzes binary classification using a simple dataset (ships on uncluttered backgrounds). More realistic settings involve multiple classes and cluttered scenes, presenting a harder challenge. Furthermore, the original papers do not explore the properties of the embedding space that lead to better alignment, required for real-world tasks.

To gain insight into how to apply EO-to-SAR transfer in practice, this paper studies these issues of multi-class classification and properties of the embedding space. We performed the analysis using Sentinel-1 (EO) and Sentinel-2 (SAR) satellite data and provide evidence that:

* SWD embedding alignment for EO-to-SAR transfer can be scaled to the multi-class setting
* Applying instance normalization leads to more stable training and better performance
* Applying contrastive learning improves the transfer performance of the SWD approach

2 Data & Methods

The So2Sat LCZ42 dataset is used for local climate zone classification, consisting of LCZ labels for approximately half a million Sentinel-1 (EO) and Sentinel-2 (SAR) satellite image patches over 42 cities across the world. Each patch has a resolution of 32x32 pixels and is labeled with one of 17 total classes (ten urban zone types, seven natural zone types). Each zone type is identified by a unique combination of surface structure, cover, and human activity at the local scale (10^2 to 10^4 m). Originally designed for urban heat island research, LCZ classification also provides significant information, such as the pervious surface fraction and surface albedo values of each zone, in applications to green infrastructure, population assessment, and ecosystem processes (Stewart and Oke, 2020).

Transfer Learning with Sliced Wasserstein Distance (SWD-transfer)

Our work builds on a recent method that trains a Y-shaped neural network (Rostami et al., 2019b) to transfer knowledge from the EO to the SAR domain. The network consists of a shared encoder and two separate decoders, one for each modality.
